items.title: How to show the differences between schema versions?
items.body:
When you are changing an API is really useful show all changes to help the developer detect breaking changes.
Is there a way to it?

A very good example in action:
```
➜ elm diff mdgriffith/elm-style-animation 3.5.5 4.0.0
This is a MAJOR change.

---- Animation - MAJOR ----

    Added:
        type alias Color = { red : Int, green : Int, blue : Int, alpha : Float }
        renderPairs : Animation msgA -> List ( String, String )

    Changed:
      - easing : { duration : Time, ease : Float -> Float } -> Interpolation
      + easing :
            { duration : Milliseconds, ease : Float -> Float } -> Interpolation

      - wait : Time -> Step msg
      + wait : Posix -> Step msg

```

items.title: No License
items.body: Please add a license file so that we know the terms of use for this project and who owns the copyright. Thanks!

items.title: Add entrypoint to pass SSL verification option
items.body: For some cases, a service is trusted and making an API call doesn't require verification. There should be an entrypoint in the client to set the verify that will be used in the session send.

items.title: Remove dependency on itypes or take over maintenance
items.body:
Hi!

The itypes dependency doesn't appear to be actively maintained (eg tomchristie/itypes#9).
Could core-api either fork it/take over ownership or else remove the dependency on it?

Many thanks :-)

items.title: [version-3]  'CoreJSONCodec' object has no attribute 'dump'

DRF failures rendering to CoreJSON:

```
../../../ve/drf-38/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/template/response.py:106: in render
    self.content = self.rendered_content
rest_framework/response.py:72: in rendered_content
    ret = renderer.render(self.data, accepted_media_type, context)
rest_framework/renderers.py:900: in render
    return codec.dump(data, indent=indent)
E   AttributeError: 'CoreJSONCodec' object has no attribute 'dump'
```

items.title: Proxy settings in session instances not honored.

milestone.description:
* Simplify Document. (Support Schema styles only, not mixed hypermedia with both data and links)
* Include typesystem in the core library. (No more `coreschema`)
* Include OpenAPI support in the core library.
* Cleanup an existing deprecations that have been pending.

items.body: When creating a client with a request.Sessions instance the proxies field is ignored. While proxies may be configured via environment variables, they should also be configurable via session objects.

items.title: Merge environment settings for SSL requests
items.body:
Hello,
Using v2.3.3, I can't make requests to an SSL endpoint:

```python
import coreapi

client = coreapi.Client()
schema = client.get('https://my-service.url/docs/:443')
```

```
requests.exceptions.SSLError: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='my-service.url', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: /docs/ (Caused by SSLError(SSLError(1, '[SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed (_ssl.c:645)'),))
```

According to [this issue](https://github.com/requests/requests/issues/4256) in the requests repo, environment settings need to be explicitely added to the `session.send` call in `coreapi/transports/http.py`:

```python
    def transition(self, link, decoders, params=None, link_ancestors=None, force_codec=False):
        # ...
        settings = session.merge_environment_settings(request.url, None, None, None, None)
        response = session.send(request, **settings)
        result = _decode_result(response, decoders, force_codec)
        # ...
```

This fixes the issue for me and I'm able to make requests to my service.

I have opened #153.

items.title: HTTPTransport ignores credentials

milestone.description:
* Simplify Document. (Support Schema styles only, not mixed hypermedia with both data and links)
* Include typesystem in the core library. (No more `coreschema`)
* Include OpenAPI support in the core library.
* Cleanup an existing deprecations that have been pending.

items.body:
Using coreapi-cli, JWT authentication failed for me:

```$ coreapi credentials add localhost "JWT `curl -s -d "username=user&password=pass" http://localhost:8000/jwt/ | cut -d\\\" -f 4`"
$ coreapi get --debug http://localhost:8000/schema
> GET /schema HTTP/1.1
> Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
> Connection: keep-alive
> Accept: application/coreapi+json, application/vnd.coreapi+json, */*
> Host: localhost
> User-Agent: coreapi
< 301 Moved Permanently
< Content-Length: 0
< Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
< Date: Fri, 05 Jan 2018 14:54:47 GMT
< Location: /schema/
< Server: WSGIServer/0.2 CPython/3.5.2

....```

No ```Authorization``` header was sent.

I figured out this line was incorrect:

https://github.com/core-api/python-client/blob/master/coreapi/transports/http.py#L352

Changing it to ```session.auth = DomainCredentials(credentials)``` fixed it for me.

items.title: Unable to specify type for list elements
Unable to specify arbitrary query parameters
items.body:
I have a paginated web API end-point, that expects `?limit=foo`, when I run:

``` python
client.action(schema, actions, params={'limit':200})
```

I see:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "timeseries.py", line 11, in <module>
    response = client.action(schema, actions, params={"limit": 2000})
  File "/home/lwm/.local/share/virtualenvs/carbondoomsday-IdcgiUO9/lib/python3.5/site-packages/coreapi/client.py", line 165, in action
    _validate_parameters(link, params)
  File "/home/lwm/.local/share/virtualenvs/carbondoomsday-IdcgiUO9/lib/python3.5/site-packages/coreapi/client.py", line 80, in _validate_parameters
    raise exceptions.ParameterError(errors)
coreapi.exceptions.ParameterError: {'limit': 'Unknown parameter.'}
```

Something I'm doing wrong or?

items.title: Using the `format=foo` kwarg for client.action
items.body:
I saw in the examples:

```
data = client.action(document, ['flights', 'search'], params={
    'from': 'LHR',
    'to': 'PA',
    'date': '2016-10-12'
})
```

But I want to also return this payload in CSV format, say. I saw that `client.get` supports `format=csv`, but I cannot do this with `client.action` or?

items.title: Add Python 3 trove classifiers to setup.py
items.body:
To help assist tools like https://caniusepython3.com/ it would be useful to add Python 3 trove classifiers to setup.py, eg:
```
Programming Language :: Python :: 3
Programming Language :: Python :: 3.4
Programming Language :: Python :: 3.5
```

items.title: Client session parameter is not used
items.body:
https://github.com/core-api/python-client/blob/master/coreapi/client.py#L99

Looks like `session` should get passed to `get_default_transports()` but it is not. I hit this bug pretty quickly.

items.title: Creating Document Fields restricted to a list of values
items.body:
I want to create an enumerated list of values that are allowed for a Field object.
Does the Python client currently allow this?

As per [this page in the Documentation](http://core-api.github.io/python-client/api-guide/document/), I don't see an option such as `enum` or anything else to do this.

Eventually, I would like to see a dropdown of these values on my Swagger UI.

items.title: Enum schema are not decoded
items.body:
On coreapi 2.3.0 with an API running DRF 3.6.2, I'm having an error when decoding documents with enum types in the `decode_schema_from_corejson` function. The `coreschema.Enum` class which unlike the other Schema class is initializing with one `enum` positional argument (the list of possible values) for validation purpose. This list is not directly available in the document so I'm not sure how you would like to initialize the class in that case.

The solutions I'm seeing is either to add the enums to the document (maybe it's already the case and I missed this part) and initialize the class properly or make the enum optional as a keyword argument for now.

items.title: Iterable links
items.body:
Hi,

I think I've hot a bit of an issue with the links in my HAL documents. I think the correct place to raise this is in this project because my best guess is the solution will be found here rather than in the HAL code.

So I get this JSON structure returned:

```
{
  "_links": {
    "list": {
      "href": "/v1/pbx/extension?domainId=ORB1234567"
    },
    "relations": [
      {
        "href": "/v1/pbx/domain/id/ORB1234567",
        "name": "domain"
      },
      {
        "href": "/v1/pbx/device?domainId=ORB1234567",
        "name": "devices"
      }
    ],
    "self": {
      "href": "/v1/pbx/extension/domainId/ORB1234567/id/1000"
    }
  },
  "callidName": "The Manager",
  "callidNumber": "1000",
  "domainId": "ORB1234567",
  "email": "manager.user@some-domain.com",
  "firstName": "Manager",
  "id": "1000",
  "lastName": "User",
}
```

Which produces a copreapi.document.Document looking something like this when printed out:
```
<Document "https://rest.orbtalk.com/v1/pbx/extension/domainId/ORB1234567/id/1000">
    callidName: "The Manager"
    callidNumber: "1000"
    domainId: "ORB1234567"
    email: "manager.user@some-domain.com"
    firstName: "Manager"
    id: "1000"
    lastName: "User"
    relations: {
        devices()
        domain()
    }
    list()
```

So I can access the list() action with no problems. However I am having trouble calling the links inside my relations object. The HAL code seems to read it fine and it does detected the links correctly, however Document.links does not find those links because it does not look inside any iterable items when searching for links.

My suggestion is that I send in a PR that patches Document.links to look recursively inside each item for links. The slightly awkward issue then however is what they should be named. In my example above it seems reasonable to me that links might be created called "relations.domain" and "relations.devices". This gets more awkward though with lists of links that HAL does support - or nesting beyond a single level of depth.

An alternative approach could be a different way of being able to call links that are contained inside other items. I'm not sure if that might already be supported or if that would break the way the client is designed to work.

Any guidance that could be provided would be great. I'm more than happy to send in PR requests for review if that would help move this along.

items.title: JSON encoding is broken with Requests v2.8.0
items.body:
2.8.0 has a bug, [(fixed in v2.8.1)](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/requests/#id14) that broke JSON encoding when using [`session.prepare_request`](https://github.com/core-api/python-client/blob/master/coreapi/transports/http.py#L186). 

Perhaps the requirements should be updated to exclude that version?

items.title: Exception Value: __new__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'description'
items.body:
When upgrading to 2.2.x, I got the following error:
`Exception Value: __new__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'description'`
in 
`File "lib/python3.5/site-packages/django_filters/rest_framework/backends.py:104" in get_schema_fields
`
Downgrading to 2.1.1 fix this. If this is the wanted behaviour, we might need to fix `django_filters`.

items.title: Provide a plugin mechanism for authentication
items.body:
Providing a means for the client to authenticate against an API endpoint is an important requirement for many consumers. This issue proposes the development of a plugin system for handling client authentication.

As was mentioned in [#114](https://github.com/core-api/python-client/issues/114) there are a few important topics to consider:

1. What set of auth policies might we need to support?
2. What does an example auth flow look like?
3. What information does the scheme itself need to present in order to make that possible?

items.title: Best way to handle "application/problem+json"
items.body:
Hi there,

The framework I am using (https://github.com/zalando/connexion) returns validation errors as Content-Type  "application/problem+json" (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7807) and this generates an error for me using Core API:

```
coreapi.exceptions.NoCodecAvailable: Unsupported media in Content-Type header 'application/problem+json'
```

As a kind of hackish test, I have created a file jsonproblem.py to make available a new codec JSONProbemCodec which does nothing apart from provide a different media type:

```
# coding: utf-8
from coreapi.codecs.jsondata import JSONCodec

class JSONProblemCodec(JSONCodec):
    media_type = 'application/problem+json'
```

So my question is two-fold really.

1. Am I going about this the right way - is this the best way to add support for a very simple new JSON media type?
2. If this is the way to go, would you accept a PR into this repository or should I create an independant pip package (which seems like overkill to me)?

Any advice appreciated. I'm keen to recommend coreapi as a simple python interface for our customers to use with our new API, but I just need to iron a few teething issues first. This is the first issue I have hit during testing.

items.title: Custom Fields 'Attributes'
items.body:
Hi,

Current Field specification is quite restrictive in terms of supported attributes. For example, if a final user is interested in rendering the specification using Swagger, there are several attributes like enum that can't be used right now. In order to make possible to add more attributes and not being coupled to a concrete rendering specification, would it be possible to add a dictionary attribute as part of the Field namedtuple for collecting them?. Then final renderers can use such dictionary for including more elements

items.title: Make it compatible with Open API V2
items.body:
It will be very nice to make core-api compatible with Open API V2.
I'd like to use `summary` and custom `responses` for my documentation.
https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/master/versions/2.0.md#operation-object
https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/master/versions/2.0.md#responsesObject
Anything planned?

items.title: `session` argument and property for Client.
items.body:
Given that HTTPTransport will be so ubiquitous, it seems reasonable to include a `session` argument on `Client`, as well as a `session` property.

As part of this we should also review `HTTPTransport` and ensure that we're deferring work (eg custom headers) to the session wherever possible, rather than handling it ourselves.

items.title: tempfile._TemporaryFileWrapper not available under Google Appengine
items.body:
Google appengine replaces the tempfile module with a custom one (since you can't write to the FS under "traditional" GAE): https://code.google.com/p/googleappengine/source/browse/trunk/python/google/appengine/dist/tempfile.py

However this module lacks the `_TemporaryFileWrapper` on which `utils.DownloadedFile` is based: https://github.com/core-api/python-client/blob/master/coreapi/utils.py#L119

Given that `_TemporaryFileWrapper` is an undocumented API (class) IMHO the dependency on it should be removed.

items.title: Wheel support
items.body:
http://pythonwheels.com/

Right now, only the `tar.gz` file is being distributed on PyPI for [coreapi](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/coreapi), which isn't _that much_ of an issue, but it does add some time to installing the package.

This package should be compatible with the Wheel format, considering it doesn't appear to have any C dependencies and it is compatible with both Python 2 and 3. As a result, you should only need to generate a universal wheel and then everyone (on all systems) will get the ability to install coreapi with just the wheel, without having to do any extra work.

---

Note that this also applies to all of the other Core API modules which are published as Python packages.

items.title: multipart falls back to urlencoded if no files are included.
base_url not used by codec.load() if url supplied by schema
items.body:
Hi, I've been using the coreapi client by reading a schema file something like this:

```
input_file = open(filename, 'rb')
input_bytes = input_file.read()
input_file.close()
codec = codecs.CoreJSONCodec()
base_url="http://localhost:9090"  # override base_url for testing
doc = codec.load(input_bytes, base_url=base_url)
```

Note that the url is already supplied in the schema file. I would expect that the `base_url` parameter would override the url provided in the schema, but it does not. Is this by design? The `base_url` parameter is not documented. If this behavior is by design, what is the mechanism by which one can override the url of the server? (say, for testing a client against an alternate server)

items.title: Where did HTML/HAL go?
items.body: It appears some of the documented codecs have gone from the codebase. Did HAL and HTML move somewhere else? These are currently highlight somewhat prominently in the docs.

```
    self.run_command(cmd)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/distutils/dist.py", line 972, in run_command
    cmd_obj.run()
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/setuptools/command/bdist_egg.py", line 209, in run
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/setuptools/command/bdist_egg.py", line 245, in zip_safe
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/setuptools/command/bdist_egg.py", line 355, in analyze_egg
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/setuptools/command/bdist_egg.py", line 392, in scan_module
ValueError: bad marshal data (unknown type code)
An error occurred when trying to install coreapi 1.31.0. Look above this message for any errors that were output by easy_install.
While:
  Installing django.
  Getting distribution for 'coreapi==1.31.0'.
Error: Couldn't install: coreapi 1.31.0
```

I guess, there're python files in the distribution pre-compiled for the wrong version of the python interpreter.

items.title: Remove `location='header'`.
items.body: Taken cue froths one from OpenAPI, but I'd be more comfortable seeing it removed until absolutely convinced it's worthwhile. (eg problematic that the parameter name has to be the HTTP header)

items.title: dump should return content, not (content_type, content)
items.body: If needed introduce a new function.

items.title: Document representations should not include leading `u`
items.body: Unicode strings in documents should display gracefully.

items.title: `.action()` should accept a string.
items.body: Accept simple dot-separated string instead of list of strings.

items.title: Attaching transport classes to documents.
items.body: When using a non-requests client (eg a coreapi transport that uses the django test client) we'll need some way of ensuring that subsequent transitions also run using the same transport.

items.title: Error responses.
items.body: Start with just `messages`. Field errors can come later.

items.title: Support Documents as parameters.
items.body: Encoded to URLs

items.title: Integration tests.
items.body: Might be useful?... http://theyougen.blogspot.co.uk/2012/10/my-best-python-http-test-server-so-far.html

items.title: Unicode strings throughout.
items.body:
Use `from __future__ import unicode_strings` everywhere.
Check `__repr__` returns correct type under both python 2 and 3.

items.title: Validate that link parameters are valid primatives.
items.body: Parameters must be primatives, documents, file objects.

items.title: Add missing immutable operations.
items.body:
- `insert`
- `append`
- `extend`
- `[deep_]*`

items.title: Document strings should use relative URLs for child nodes.
Link errors.
items.body:
- [x] Encoding.
- [x] Decoding.
- [x] Links to validate field names?

items.title: Consider naming for `.action` method.
items.body: `action()` may not be the best name for calling links, particularly as `'action'` is a specific link transition type consider `.call()`, `.link()`?

items.title: Graceful document display for empty elements.
items.body:
String representation for documents should handle:
- [x] Empty object as `{}` (no newlines)
- [x] Empty array as `[]` (no newlines)
- [x] Empty document as `<Name - 'url'>` (no newlines)
- [x] No url as `<Name>`.
- [x] Title should use `.strip()`
- [x] No title as `<Document>`

items.title: Handle `Link` gracefully in JSON codec.
items.body:
- URL not a string.
- rel not a string.
- fields do not match correct format.

items.title: Use `base_url` in JSON codec.
items.body:
- When decoding, URLs should be relative to parent documents.
- When encoding use relative URLs if host:scheme matches parent.
- Documents should display URLs as relative if host:scheme matches parent.

items.title: Raise `DocumentError` on malformed documents.
items.body:
- `meta` not included.
- `meta` not an object.
- `meta.url` not included.
- `meta.url` not a string.
- `meta.title` not a string.
- `meta.<other>` included.
- `Link` in `Array`.
- `Link` with invalid name pattern.
